handFeeding.purpose: Build engagement, relationship and create value for training
implementation: Use meals as training opportunities (especially breakfast and dinner)
Feed kibble piece by piece for desired behaviors
Gradually transition from continuous to intermittent reinforcement
Maintain hand feeding portion even as puppy grows
Use meal time to teach impulse control and calm behavior

calmness.purpose: Develop a puppy who can self-regulate and settle
implementation: Reward calm behavior from day one
Practice 'passive training' - reward spontaneous calm moments
Use structured relaxation protocol daily
Create clear distinctions between play time and calm time
Never reward excitement, jumping or demanding behaviors
Teach settle on a specific mat or place
Maintain consistent daily schedule
Use consistent verbal cues and hand signals
Practice brief training sessions multiple times daily
End all interactions on success
Create clear thresholds (doorways, entering/exiting crate)
Establish predictable patterns for key activities

engagement.purpose: Build relationship and focus to enable effective training
implementation: Use movement and enthusiasm to build interest
Work in short bursts with high success rate
Incorporate play into training
Build value for eye contact and name recognition
Create motivation rather than relying on bribery
Be more interesting than distractions

environmentalManagement.purpose: Prevent unwanted behaviors and set up for success
implementation: Use appropriate confinement (crate, playpen) when not supervising
Puppy-proof accessible areas completely
Gradually expand freedom as reliability increases
Manage exposure to distractions based on training level
Control excitement levels in the environment
Provide appropriate outlet for natural behaviors

socialization.purpose: Create confident, well-adjusted dog without overwhelming
implementation: Focus on quality over quantity of exposures
Ensure puppy is calm before exposure to new things
Practice 'look but don't touch' with novel stimuli
Monitor body language and emotional state during exposure
Create positive associations with neutral experiences
Never force interactions - allow choice and agency
Master behaviors in quiet environments before adding distractions
Add the 3 D's gradually: Duration, Distance, Distraction
Keep sessions short but frequent (5-10 sessions of 1-3 minutes daily)
Balance obedience training with life skills (handling, calmness)
Use marker word ('yes') consistently to identify desired behavior
Create structured training plans with clear criteria for each step

feeding.dailyAmount: 2-3 cups of high-quality puppy food (specific to large breeds)
feeding.method: Hand-feed at least one meal per day for training and bonding
tips: Measure each meal precisely to avoid overfeeding
Use kibble from daily allowance for training sessions
Ensure fresh water is always available
Monitor stool consistency - adjust amount if needed

keyFocus: Building positive associations with the crate

techniques.title: Crate Introduction
steps: Place crate in family area where Pickle can see you
Leave door open when not in use
Place comfortable bedding inside
Feed treats randomly in crate throughout day

techniques.title: Entry Training
steps: Never force Pickle into crate
Use high-value treats placed at back of crate
Toss favorite toy inside to encourage entry
Create "crate games" - toss treat in, let her get it, call her out, repeat
Use consistent cue word (e.g., "crate" or "bed")

techniques.title: Duration Building
steps: Start with door open while Pickle explores
Close door briefly while feeding high-value treats
Gradually extend door-closed time (5 seconds → 10 → 30 → 1 minute)
Practice departures: close crate, walk few steps away, return immediately

techniques.title: Nighttime Crating
steps: Establish consistent bedtime routine (potty break, calm activities)
Place crate near your bed initially
Use special nighttime-only treats for crate entry
Expect to take Pickle out 1-2 times during night for potty

techniques.title: Troubleshooting
steps: For resistance, back up to shorter durations
If whining occurs, only let Pickle out when quiet (even momentarily)
Cover crate on three sides if Pickle seems over-stimulated
Place item with your scent in crate for comfort

techniques.title: Potty Schedule
steps: Take outside immediately after: waking, eating, drinking, playing, napping
Proactive hourly trips outside when active
Last potty break right before crate/bed

techniques.title: Success Protocol
steps: Use consistent potty area outside
Give potty cue word as Pickle eliminates ("go potty")
Immediate praise and high-value treat after completion
Wait for both urination and defecation before coming inside

techniques.title: Accident Management
steps: Supervise constantly or confine to crate when cannot watch
If caught in act, interrupt with neutral sound, take immediately outside
Never punish accidents after the fact
Clean accidents with enzymatic cleaner
Track accidents to identify patterns

techniques.title: Nighttime Protocol
steps: Restrict water 2-3 hours before bedtime (not completely)
Set alarm for overnight potty break(s) - typically every 3-4 hours
Keep nighttime breaks boring and brief (no play)
Track nighttime intervals to identify bladder capacity

techniques.title: Signals Recognition
steps: Watch for circling, sniffing, whining, door scratching
Respond immediately to potential signals
Begin doorbell/potty bell introduction

dailySchedule.notes: Keep boring, just for elimination; establish consistent routine
Gentle play to burn morning energy while avoiding over-arousal
Use as mini training session with kibble; practice sits and eye contact
Always follow meals with potty break; use consistent cue word
Short, focused training with remaining breakfast kibble; high success rate
Will Atherton's 'calm settle' practice on a mat
Monitor closely for potty signals; interrupt undesirable behaviors
Proactive hourly break; praise calmly for success
Morning nap; build positive crate association; use calm energy when crating
Immediately after waking from nap; maintain consistency
Controlled exposure to new stimulus; focus on quality over quantity
Proactive break; establish elimination locations
Mid-morning nap; begin building duration; practice departures
Immediately after waking from nap
Gentle introduction to collar pressure; reward loose leash position
Monitor closely for potty signals; practice interruption-free attention
Continue reinforcing calm behavior around food
Always follow meals with potty break
Structured play with clear start/end signals; teach impulse control
Focus on one skill; high rate of reinforcement; end on success
After play session
Afternoon nap; close crate door; practice being calm while alone
Immediately after waking from nap
Short, positive training focusing on engagement and relationship
New textures, surfaces, sounds; build environmental confidence
Practice 'place' command intermittently during free time
Proactive hourly break
Hide treats/toys for searching; develop problem-solving skills
Late afternoon nap; build duration gradually
Immediately after waking from nap
Structured game with rules; reinforce self-control
Practice touching paws, ears, mouth with positive association
Use as training opportunity; build food manners
Always follow meals with potty break
Integrate with family activities, monitor for potty signals
Proactive hourly break
Begin winding down for evening; practice massage, gentle petting
Evening elimination
Quiet time with family, minimal excitement; practice calm behavior
Final elimination before bed; use calm energy
Use bedtime-only treat, expect 1-2 overnight potty breaks
Keep boring, minimal interaction, no play; maintain consistency
Keep boring, minimal interaction, no play; prepare for return to crate

feeding.dailyAmount: 3-4 cups of high-quality puppy food (specific to large breeds)
feeding.schedule: 3 meals per day, transitioning to 2 meals by 16 weeks
feeding.method: Hand-feed portions of meals during training sessions
tips: Begin transitioning to twice-daily feeding at 14-15 weeks
Monitor growth rate - Golden Retrievers should grow steadily but not rapidly
Reserve 1/4 to 1/3 of daily kibble for training rewards

techniques.title: Duration Extension
steps: Build to 1-2 hour crating periods during day
Begin crating during meal preparation or shower time
Create predictable crate schedule
Practice random crating throughout day (10-15 minutes)

techniques.title: Reward Adjustment
steps: Transition from treats every time to intermittent rewards
Praise for calm crate behavior
Special toys reserved only for crate time
Frozen Kong with small amount of peanut butter for longer stays

techniques.title: Location Transitions
steps: Begin moving crate gradually to desired permanent location
If nighttime crate is separate, maintain consistency in both locations
Practice with crate door closed but you visible, then you hidden

techniques.title: Confidence Building
steps: Add "place" or "bed" command as formal cue
Practice sending to crate from increasing distances
Reward for spontaneous crate use

techniques.title: Troubleshooting
steps: If regression occurs, temporarily return to more frequent rewards
Never use crate as punishment
For anxiety, try calming music or white noise

techniques.title: Schedule Evolution
steps: Extend to 2-3 hour intervals during daytime
Maintain consistency with after waking/eating/playing breaks
Begin tracking natural elimination patterns

techniques.title: Communication Development
steps: Actively train potty signal (bell, specific bark, sitting at door)
Consistent practice: guide Pickle to signal before each potty break
Heavily reward signal when offered independently

techniques.title: Reliability Building
steps: Track successful days vs. accident days
Identify triggers for accidents (excitement, specific visitors)
Implement management for identified trigger situations

techniques.title: Nighttime Progress
steps: Extend to 4-5 hour overnight intervals if possible
Begin phasing out middle-of-night break if consistently dry

techniques.title: Troubleshooting
steps: If accidents increase, temporarily return to more frequent breaks
For specific accident locations, block access or change environment
Check for UTI if previously reliable puppy begins having accidents

Begin brief moments of out-of-sight supervision
